25161366.trustfund:
TF026232-PHRD-RURAL INVESTMENT FUND (RIF),TF040913-ZAMBIA: AGRICULTURE SECTOR
            INVESTMENT PROJECT II,BBFAO-BB FAO

abstracts.cdata!:
The Agricultural Development Support
            Project for Zambia has a satisfactory outcome rating. The
            rick to development is low or negligible; the Bank's
            performance is satisfactory; and the borrower's
            performance is satisfactory. This project supports increased
            commercialization of smallholder agriculture through
            improved productivity, quality and efficiency of value
            chains where smallholders participate. The project
            development objective was not changed during implementation.
            With respect to the key performance indicators, the mid-term
            review noted that the National Coordination Office (NCO)
            faced issues in regularly updating the indicators due to
            unclear data collection methodology and analysis between the
            NCO and the project implementing agencies (IAs). The
            indicators were therefore revised to better link to the
            components and logically reflect the impact of ongoing
            activities specifically supported by the project. The
            revised key performance indicators were: i) agricultural
            exports for target value chains (tons/year); ii) targeted
            commodities produced by smallholder householders
            (tons/year); iii) smallholder households growing targeted
            crops (number); iv) average income per household in targeted
            areas; and v) direct project beneficiaries (number), of
            which females (percent). Improved value chain productivity,
            quality and efficiency were assessed using above key
            performance indicators in terms of increases in volumes and
            numbers. There are six major lessons learned from the
            project. First, innovations in project design, which the
            project had in the Market Improvement and Innovation
            Facility and Rural Roads Improvement Facility components,
            should address capacity limitations upfront in order to
            assure implementation success. In general, projects of this
            type need to take into account country capacity in project.
            Second, the OPRC-type contract, where road rehabilitation
            design includes sufficient resources and practical
            arrangements for post-rehabilitation maintenance for several
            years, combined in one contract proved successful. Third,
            the link between producers and markets is critical in a
            project that seeks to increase commercialization in
            agriculture. Fourth, strengthening government core functions
            can build private sector trust in government. Fifth, good
            continuous monitoring; periodic and regular evaluation; and
            quality impact assessments played an important role in
            learning from the project throughout implementation, and
            once it was completed. Sixth, flexibility and being
            opportunistic in implementation was key to the success of
            this project.
